Comment: [President Donald Trumpâ€™s â€œbig beautiful billâ€ is running into a wall](https://www.cnn.com/2025/05/07/politics/medicaid-republicans-divided-house-trump-bill?utm_medium=social&utm_source=reddit) in the sharply divided House Republican conference, with tensions spiking over Speaker Mike Johnsonâ€™s handling of the partyâ€™s biggest sticking point: overhauling Medicaid.  As Johnson presses for a House vote before Memorial Day, the battlelines are becoming more pronounced, with Republicans in swing districts saying the sweeping bill canâ€™t slash social safety net benefits while GOP hardliners are demanding trillions more in spending cuts â€“ far beyond what many centrist members are willing to swallow.  Those frustrations emerged in a two-hour meeting in Johnsonâ€™s leadership suite on Tuesday night, in which the speaker huddled with roughly a dozen GOP centrists who have refused to back any Medicaid changes that could hurt eligible Americans who rely on the program.  Inside the room, Johnson made one more attempt to sell those members on a contentious plan â€” backed by the hard-right House Freedom Caucus and others â€” to sharply reduce Medicaid payments to states that expanded the program under Obamacare, according to two people in the room. His push drew a rebuke from multiple centrists in the room, who believed that idea was already off the table, the people said.  â€œWe laid down the law,â€ one Republican member who had attended the meeting said of the firm position many members took.

Comment: Kabuki theater.... it doesn't matter - there will be a package and the Dems will vote for it...  Currently the GOP tries to push this through reconciliation, but it will fail as there are too many factions not on board with parts of this plan. Moderate Blue state GOP-ers won't go for Medicaid cuts and want SALT caps raised. Fiscal conservatives want to cut more cost and won't go for lifting SALT caps.  Eventually a plan will be found that Trump will push for (he has no ideological stance and doesn't care about debt). But it will result in the GOP not being able to push this through reconciliation and will come to regular order.  Likely it's too 'big' and too 'beautiful' for the Freedom Caucus and they won' t be on board and will withhold their votes. So the GOP needs Dem votes to get it through regular order...  Now, the deal also contains lifting the debt ceiling and not doing so will cause the financial system to IMplode, as our system requires debt to grow.  The Dems will get weak in the knees and deliver the votes to get it through, while the fiscal conservatives can keep claiming they are against Govt largess.  At that point, the Dems became part of this administration.
